												Atom Zombie Smasher is a super little indie strategy game.  The basic premise is that you take on the guise of a commander holding back the zombie hordes from overruning your city.  It works on two levels; first is the strategy where a map of the city districts is where you see the progress of zombie infestations and plan your next mission.  You can choose which military assets you take with you from: infantry, snipers, mines, demolitions, barricades, gas attracting teams or artillery.  Once you initiate the mission, the game changes to a tactical sub-game where you place your units on the map to best protect the civilians you are trying to extract from the map, while avoiding collateral damage.  To many dead civilians and you fail.There are a number of tactical elements that affect each mission type such as: map layout, dangerous area which can explode if you are not careful, more or less time-limit & available/unavailable units.You win if you extract a minimum number of civilians or your units are able to destroy the encroaching zed hordes.  However if you do not clear the map of zeds before nightfall more zeds arrive to swarm the map.  Successful missions reward you with points that go towards an overall victory target.  Units also receive XP to increase their unique zed destroying abilities and they can level up to increase those abilites to make them more clincial.The zeds then receive strategic points allocated to some city district (1-4) which determines the strength of the zombie hordes and the difficulty of initiating a mission there.  This continues until you reach the campaign victory target.Though gameplay is fairly repetitive the addition of custom campaign options make the strategy and tactical aspects that much more varied.  Scientists can be found wondering the city area and can be rescued.  Each one can then be "spent" to acquire research upgrades towards 8 specific areas of interest including: faster xp gains for units, faster strategic weapons, resilient scientist, more destructive weapons etc).  You can have access to strategic and tactical weapons that can clear zeds from an entire district thus reseting the danger level there.  Just be aware of the monster-zeds! lolFor me this was a surprise gem of a game.  While graphics are just basic sprites, it really can grab you if you let it.  It one of the most intelligently designed games Ive ever played and almost perfectly balanced.  While the musical score and audio is fairly basic, they do a wonderful job of immersing you in unfolding events.  Best of all its a very polished game.   Even if some Mac users are having problems with playing it.If you are after a basic but enjoyable zombie apocalypse survival simulator then you should pick up a copy when the price is right for you!

It's called Atom Zombie Smasher. Yes, there are zombies, yes, you smash them, with atomic bombs...The title is as literal as it comes, perhaps second only to NZA 2 (read my review on -that- for more details) in terms of "It does what it says on the tin". Atom Zombie smasher is a variant on those old-school top down "Zombie outbreak simulator" programs that would show lots of little dots rushing around, some were coloured as civilians, and others as zombies, over time you'd watch the infection spread throughout the city, often leaving a small clump of survivors holed up in a dead end praying to survive just another few moments.This is the logical conclusion of that program, it's a game and a campaign structured around the outbreak simulator program, with you tasked as the last remaining commander of the available defence forces, attempting to save as many lives (and smash as many zombies) as you can. To this end you're provided with a default escape helicopter, and gradually introduced to the toolbox of mercenaries that accompany you over the course of the campaign.More than just a zombie infection simulator...The game runs two distinct "beats", the first is the strategic map, a somewhat procedurally generated vision of a large city with lots of sub districts. This map operates on something of a turn based mode, so at the beginning of a given month, the zombie AI places outbreak counters on various districts, you then select a district to fight in, and depending on the outcome the district is either still infested, cleared out, or reclaimed and made safe for humanity. So far so normal, it's important to note however that whilst you only get ONE district to fight each month, the outbreak AI gets two, and eventually three counters to use, you're fighting a losing battle overall.However, on the upside, you -do- get some tools at various points, in the strategic map the two major events are access to a prototype cannon (Elephantbird) that allows you to utterly eradicate a district in the tactical mode (more on this shortly), and llama bombs, which essentially decontaminate a bunch of districts in one pass, buying you much needed breathing room. Outside of this, you'll be assigned a squad of mercenaries (randomly selected from the available pool), and you'll get to choose a district to "go tactical" on.Getting down and dirty with the undead masses...This is where the outbreak simulator program is most visible, in the tactical mode you're presented with a moderately simple top down view, with civilians represented in a sortof beige yellow, zeds in purple, and your forces taking up various other colours. Left unchecked, the map will play out much like the software in question, and eventually all the survivors will be gobbled up, but you've tools to prevent this!Before the tactical map kicks off, you designate your initial landing point for your rescue chopper (equipped with foghorn that automatically attracts nearby civilians), and you set up your various mercenaries. These range from single shot items like minefields, to ongoing and mobile defences such as infantry and snipers. Effective use and the setting up of choke-points can, if done right, result in you demolishing all the zombies before nightfall and scoring a hefty bonus (indeed, these bonuses, and saving lots of survivors is your path to victory).We have explosive...The game really livens up once you've got explosives, with the map turning from an often pristine cityscape into a big brown muddy pit. Zombies exploding in clouds of green as your artillery rains down, remote dynamite detonations at key junctions reducing swarms of zombies into kibble, and your infantry protecting choke points and keeping the zeds away from the ever dwindling number of survivors. Once there are no more survivors to rescue, the scores are tallied up and you're returned to the strategic map. Learning how to adapt your tactics to an ever growing outbreak, and racing to the victory of humanity before the zeds inevitably take over forms the core of the campaign.Blendo hits one out of the park, with an off the wall look at zombie apocalypses...For a simple pick up and play title, it offers an excellent level of depth, combined with an offbeat and catchy soundtrack. The graphics are not much to look at, but they do the job functionally well (think of a 3D version of that outbreak simulator and you're pretty much there). It's very easy on the system requirements and provided you don't suffer any hiccups at launch, you'll have little complaint from the game. As a cheap impulse buy, it's hard to find fault and as such, comes very much recommended.Verdict : Essential

												A top down view of the Zombie Apocalypse!Great soundtrack and effects coupled with addictive gameplay make this a surprising hit for what is a basic top down 2d game with sprites.  Kind of like a tower defense game, but without a fixed base - the people you save are essentially what you are trying to protect!The Campaign map or strategic view is where you begin.  Every turn zombies (Zeds) take over new territories. From these you choose a territory/city to attempt to rescue civilians from.  This will launch your team deployment phase - placing helicopter landing point etc.Once each turn or rescue begins, you have a set number of people you have to rescue to be successful - should you fail to hit this number, you will lose that territory.  Should you succeed, it will become neutral.  Rescue during missions is achieved by clicking with the mouse to adjust landing zone for your helicopter in a way that draws the people away from the edges of the city where the Zeds emerge from.  During the daytime when rescue missions begin, this will be from marked entrances, but on sun down, more Zeds will appear from all edges of the city!!Only people within a certain radius hear the helicopters horn and move towards it - which can later be upgrade - there is a delay until the helicopter arrives and how many people it can carry which you can also be upgraded as you progress.  You unlock new units to assist you as the campaign progresses such as mobile soldier squad, fixed artillery which you can place on a rooftop, sniper team and roadblocks to name a few.The Zed get scored on how many people they 'convert' regardless of the outcome.  At the end of the mission you are returned to the main map, and scores are added up for yourself and the zed.  At set points totals fixed events occur, such as 'Giant Zeds' etc to spice things up a bit.  Also, depending upon the month/turn, Zed will invade other territories.  The ultimate aim being to out-score the zed in what is essentially a points race - for a large part of which you will be behind in until you discover 'Llama bombs' later in the game ;-)Overall it is a great little addictive strategy game, one word of warning though, it only has the one soundtrack, so if you don't like it, you may want to turn the music off altogether!

												This game is incredible, and I should've remembered to review it years ago.  Well-designed RTT and RTS packaged up into a tiny, pulp fiction universe that's experiencing an enormous problem with the undead. Use the zombies' behaviors against them, until desperation leads to the utilization of unlucky civilians as bait in your tactical plans.  When all else fails and the cities are alive with corpses, feel free to resort to nuclear warfare and llama bombs.A pitch-perfect example of clever indie design and a willingness to make immensely creative games on a shoestring.  AZS is well-built on a foundation of intriguing swarm AI, hilarious art and slick, intuitive gameplay.  Take the plunge if you enjoy RTS, strategy or puzzle games; Atom Zombie Smasher won't disappoint.

												Atom Zombie Smasher is a game set in the ficticious South Americian-esque country of Neuvos Aires and pits you as it's leader fending off a zombie infestation. This game supports the use of a USB controller and local coop, however local coop is simply the single player game with an additional person performing actions.  There is absolutely no change to the game itself besides having a second cursor on the screen. This game also supports modding and it's all nicely built into the game options. Modding is pretty simple though and is basically just creating a configuration file to tweak behavior and attributes.One way this game falls short is that difficulty doesn't scale in extended games. I played an extended match and at a certain point it became far too easy. 												Gameplay revolves around protecting an overworld map from zombie infestations. You pick out regions to evacuate and send in troops/artillery/explosives to fight off the zombies while your chopper air-lifts civilians and scientists (for researching upgrades). It gets repetitive because each zone is randomly generated, even if you restart the current mission. However there is no way to preview what the map will look like when you choose to evac it; besides a general difficulty number, there's no sure way to prepare your loadout. This leads to occasionally forfeiting a zone and losing a turn, potentially costing you the whole campaign. Some replay value is provided by mutators which affect everything from possible loadouts to super weapon strengths.I got this in the humble indie bundle 3 and find it very entertaining in small doses. Worth checking out if you're looking for a twist on tower defense games.

												The brand of near-impossible challenge this game offers is not to my taste. There is undoubtedly a way to beat it, but several things I prefer to have direct control over are never in the player's hands to begin with.Atom Zombie Smasher focues on rescueing civilians from zones infested with zombies. You have no control over the civilians on the ground; you can only send an evacuation helicoptor and hope all the civilians get to it in time. In order to aid you in this mission, you are given control of a random set of resources.These resources are randomized for every mission, and it is this aspect to the game that I cannot stand. Sometimes you'll have access to attack dogs and snipers, other times you'll have mines and blockades. Rarely, all you'll have access to is blockades and a paltry 3 bombs with which to stem the zombie tide. Even worse, the challenges you'll face vary from times of day (fewer zombies in sunshine, etc) to superzombies that require a considerable effort to take down.Every zone you lose to the zombies gets chalked up on a big scoreboard. First to a set score wins, and it's an uphill battle for any player from the start. If I had control over my resources, I might enjoy this. However, I don't so I can't.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Who remembers this one? Back from the olden days of Winter Sale coal and fresh indie zombie games. Actually, maybe it's more appropriate to ask if you remember that decade-old zombie simulator with the colored dots, because this is the fully gameified version of that. Humanity is on the retreat from the zombie hordes and it's up to you to evacuate the survivors from your region. You can select different infested areas from the strategic map based on the infection level (difficulty), and it takes you to a small city map where you have to plan the evacuation. You get a helicopter that airlifts folks (yellow dots) out every 20 seconds or so, and up to 3 mercenary units to help defend. These units are anything from soldiers and snipers to landmines and barricades. After each mission you AND the zombies get victory points based on the final number of survivors and zombies. New events occur as you both reach certain victory point milestones, and the first side to rack up the target number of points wins.Sounds solid, right? Unfortunately, this all comes together to form a strategy game that's mostly based on random chance. Just like the old simulator, humans turn into zombies instantly when touched, and you better believe the survivors clump up around the landing zones like delicious stuffing. All it takes is one zombie escaping your best-laid deathtrap to ruin an entire map. This is further exacerbated by the fact that your 3 mercenary units are randomized for each mission. So while you're in good shape if you get your mortars and zombie baits in one mission, you're boned if you get stuck with barricades, mines, and bombs, all of which are one-use tricks. There's also random variance in the performance of your units; soldiers can miss, and your mortars can go off-target, ruining that hail mary shot you needed to save the day. There are a host of other frustrations, like how you and the zombies get points for holding territory, but you only claim territory if you kill ALL the zombies on the map before sundown, which is ludicrously difficult even if you have the right mercs for it.It's a shame, too, because the presentation is stylish and weird, and there are some neat systems to explore like XP to improve your mercs and rescuing scientists to upgrade your other abilities. The story vignettes are compellingly strange as well and I still can't make heads or tails of the story, but I know Tesla and an antichrist baby are involved. Shame I'll never figure it out, because the game's just too damn discouraging and frustrating to get through.

												I would give Atom Zombie Smasher a 6/10. It is a bird's eye view zombie evacuation game, with qualities of a tower defense game.Your goal is to evacuate citizens from various citeis of a country during a zombie outbreak. The more citizens you save, the higher your score and the more upgrades you can unlock. You have multiple weapons and tools available at your disposal to use, though these are randomly assigned to you. This is because, in my eyes, you have an entire country to defend and evacuate, as the zombies spread at an alarming rate (go figure: they are zombies) and the situation can quickly turn very bad.I found the game to be very strategic in certain instances, and less so in others. This winds up being the best strength and worst weakness of the game at the same time. When given random sets of gear, sometimes you are underpowered and stand little hope, sometimes you are given overpowered ones and it is too easy (you can sometimes have a weapon set that lets you airstrike the entire city, once you upgrade them enough: how fun and challenging), and sometimes you have a set where it is possible to succeed, but forces you to think, plan, and change tactics mid game. This is when it is at its most fun.You are able to set up a customized game if you wish, to add further challenge and some replayability. In the end though, Atom Zombie Shasher is not a long term game. It is one to play for a bit, then uninstall, then come back to on occasion once you are itching to try again. I recommend this game as long as you know are aware of that fact. Atom Zombie Smasher has a very limited way to play it, but it sure is fun for the first few times you do it. Approaching the situation as if you were actually evacuating cities from a zombie outbreak is pretty fun, and you definitely can't save everyone which adds an element of realism to a very goofy game. Don't expect to play it for 20+ hours or anything, but as a once in a while game it does its job very well. If you can find it in a humble bundle or on sale for a buck or two, it is definitely worth it.

												Atom Zombie Smasher is a my favorite Blendo Games title. It's a brilliant casual realtime strategy game that's tense, strategic, flexible, and most of all, a lot of fun. I've heard a few people describe it as "tower defense", but that's really pigeon-holing it and doing a disservice to a new player's expectations. It's true that a large portion of the strategy is in controlling the flow of the enemy, but it's not nearly as deterministic and simple as that implies. Also there are no towers. The feel of the game is much more about thinking on your feet, and dealing with disasters as they're unfolding in real (or slowed down) time.You can play any way you want by modifying the campaign settings, letting you restart levels at no cost for that perfectionist victory, or turning on permadeath and a variety of difficulty mods for more intense and less forgiving sessions.The entire game takes place in the same universe as Brendon Chung's other tiles, including Gravity Bone, 30 Flights of Loving, and Flotilla. Chung's unique humor and sensibilities come through in the form of a large number of vignettes and background articles describing the characters in and around events of the game, and the whole experience is topped off with an amazing instrumental surf rock soundtrack by The Volcanics.

												Atom Zombie Smasher is a my favorite Blendo Games title. It's a brilliant casual realtime strategy game that's tense, strategic, flexible, and most of all, a lot of fun. I've heard a few people describe it as "tower defense", but that's really pigeon-holing it and doing a disservice to a new player's expectations. It's true that a large portion of the strategy is in controlling the flow of the enemy, but it's not nearly as deterministic and simple as that implies. Also there are no towers. The feel of the game is much more about thinking on your feet, and dealing with disasters as they're unfolding in real (or slowed down) time.You can play any way you want by modifying the campaign settings, letting you restart levels at no cost for that perfectionist victory, or turning on permadeath and a variety of difficulty mods for more intense and less forgiving sessions.The entire game takes place in the same universe as Brendon Chung's other tiles, including Gravity Bone, 30 Flights of Loving, and Flotilla. Chung's unique humor and sensibilities come through in the form of a large number of vignettes and background articles describing the characters in and around events of the game, and the whole experience is topped off with an amazing instrumental surf rock soundtrack by The Volcanics.

												Atom Zombie Smasher is my favorite game, so far, to come from Blendo Games. They are a quirky game company so their games can be a mixed bag but that's very okay because they are not afraid to try new things and think outside of the box. Atom Zombie Smasher mixes RTS, tower defense, and a bit of turn based strategy. The object of the game is to rescue civilians from cities that are under zombie attack. While rescuing them, you fend off the zombies with mercenary teams that you acquire throughout the campaign. You also have to try to capture cities and strategically select cities to rescue to help stop the spread of the zombies. It's kind of like the board game, Pandemic, mixed with some tower defense. The visuals in this game are very simplistic. People and zombies are represented by cubes. It may seem like a silly decision but it actually helps to maintain a fun atmosphere to the game to have colorful cubes running around the city. Most zombie apocalypse games have dark and gritty atmospheres to create a horror setting. You won't find that here. Atom Zombie Smasher is all about the strategy and the frantic game-play. 												One way of describing Atom Zombie Smasher is to call it a real time strategy game...but I think that this still fails to fully describe the experience of playing Atom Zombie Smasher....You play as a commander who must save civilians, exterminate zombies and rid the area of Nuevos Aires of the zombie infestation in a world set in the 1960's. You are scored based on how many civilians you rescue, how many zombies you kill and how quickly you achieve this.The storyline campaign features a map of Nuevos Aires divided into regions (the number of regions can be edited according to how long you want to play for or what target score you set). Regions are coloured according to whether they are infested with zombies, have been liberated by you or have had all the life bombed out of them. Regions are also numbered to show the extent of zombie infestation, with higher numbers indicating a larger number of zombies to kill.You have access to a helicopter (which airlifts people to safety) and then attack units to use to help you kill zombies. Attack units include ground infantry, snipers, dynamite, road blocks, etc, but you can only use 4 attack units at a time. Once you have chosen a region, you launch into a square map with randomly placed buildings, roads and civilians. You will be shown where zombies will approach from and asked to place your units on the map in strategically chosen locations. When you're done, you watch as the zombies move in and the level commences. You can move a few units after placing them, but not for most of them, so you have to really think hard about where you put them.There are comic book style cutscenes which appear randomly and explain the game's backstory. The cutscenes have a certain brand of dark humour which I find hilarious, but some people might not appreciate.You can also adjust game settings to make things easier or harder depending on what you want to get out of the game. For example, you can start out with all attack units, allow zombies to spawn inside a region, allow mega zombies, etc.Overall, this is a game worth looking at if you like strategy games.

												A very light RTS style game where you strategically place randomly selected units such as Snipers or Barricades to protect your helicopters landing zone. You have a minimum amount of people to rescue on each level and anyone touched by a zombie instantly becomes one themselves. This can prove disastrous when you have the majority of the people on the map waiting at your landing zone and a lone zombie comes in and converts the entire lot of them. This really makes you plan your unit placement very carefully, which is really the core gameplay. After the match starts there’s usually not all that much to do but watch, save for a few actions such as changing your landing zone location or redirecting your snipers cover area.I was surprised by how much I enjoyed this game, this is not even a genre I would consider my favorite. There are quite a few game modes to choose from but I found the game to be very easy if you opt to be able to pick which units you use every match. I found being forced to come up with new strategies when the units were selected randomly to really be the main challenge and fun of the game.-Playtime-The game is a lot of fun for a fairly short amount of time. While you can play as many campaigns as you want with varying game modes, the core gameplay doesn’t really change much and the game will probably wear out its welcome after about 10-15 hours.-Achievements-Nothing that different from what you would do during normal gameplay, most are just accumulative achievements. Luring massive hordes with Bait into waiting Dynamite for its kill achievement was fun though. 100% becomes a grind for the 500 Gold Medals, once you have Artillery built up a matches can take less than a minute each but it's still a grind.Recommended on sale.
